BRADY HARAN: I shall be
with you shortly.
Thank you everyone.
How are you all?

My name's Brady Haran, and I
make the Numberphile videos.

I also make several other
YouTube channels, which I
might talk about in a minute.

I'm not going to be here
for very long.

I guess this is kind of
a test run for me.

I want to see how a few things
are working with the webcam

and lights and things
like that.

I've been having all
sorts of problems.

And I'm also having a new
computer delivered, so to show

you just how live this is, if
the door knocks, I'm going to

be out of here very quickly
because I missed the delivery

yesterday and I don't want
to miss it again.

The main reason I'm here is
I want to tell you about

something like this that I'm
going to be doing tomorrow at
around the same time.

Except it won't be just me
sitting here, I'll be here

with Dr. James Grime, who's in
loads of Numberphile videos.

And we're going to be doing a
bit of a live thing where I'm
going to ask him questions.

But more to the point, I'm
hoping that you're going to
ask him questions.

So if you do nothing else,
please leave some comments

underneath this video with
questions for James and things
for us to talk about.

Especially in case you can't
make it tomorrow, I'll read

your questions here in the
comments and try and make sure
we cover some of that stuff.

Basically I just want to make
sure we've got something to

talk about from the start, so
please leave any questions.

I'll remind you again about the
James thing because that's

the most important thing that I
want you to take from this.

And we're going to be doing it
at 4:00 PM UK time, which is

11:00 AM on the East Coast in
America, 8:00 AM on the West

Coast in the US, and 2:30 AM
if you are in Adelaide,
Australia, where I'm from.

I always like to give things
in Adelaide time as well.
Shooting for that.

In the meantime, you can ask me
any questions quickly now.

I'm having a quick look at
some of your comments.

There's lots of them basically
saying hello.
So, hello.
Here we go.

the periodic table obviously

So we do plan to go there

a math expert.

perhaps.

is James Grime.

He's in the most Numberphile
videos.

You can go back and have
a look who he is.
He's really good value.

"How many do you have?" How
many channels do I have, I

12 channels.

Numberphile, Deep Sky Videos
, Periodic Videos, Sixty

Symbols, Nottingham Science,

from Spain."

So the last video I put
up was the one about
statistics in football.

I live in the UK and I do call
football "football", although

I am from Australia, so I grew
up calling it soccer.

I've had a lot of comments about
that, so I thought I'd
discuss that as well.

A lot of people don't like
it when I call it soccer.

And I don't know, I think it's
kind of the right thing to do.

I said at the start of the
video, "It's football, but

some people call it soccer,"
and then I called it
soccer a few times.

Soccer obviously being a
shortening of Association
Football apparently.

And I think it's OK to call
it soccer in that context.

I mean a lot of Numberphile
viewers are American and a lot
are Australian.

And I think if I say soccer,
everyone knows what I'm
talking about.

And if I start staying football
all the time, some
people don't.

And they might get confused,
so I don't think there's

anything wrong with a few
"soccer's" in there amongst
the "football"s.

I know people feel passionately
about it.
But there you go.

And another thing I get asked a
lot about is the brown paper

in Numberphile videos,
so I thought I'd
quickly discuss that.

I've written a blog
about this.

My blog, if you ever want to
look it up, is called Periodic
Videos blogger or blogspot .

If you just google Periodic
Videos and blogger, you'll
find my blog.

And if you google Periodic
Videos and brown paper, you'll

find the blog that I
wrote about this.

And I always point
people to it.

But let me talk you quickly
through the brown paper.

Basically when I started
Numberphile, I knew there was

going to be a lot of writing
involved from the people in

the films, the mathematicians
and
scientists and other guests.

And I wanted to make that a
feature of the videos .

I considered blackboards, I
considered buying little

slates and chalkboards, because
I thought that might

be nice, but in the end I
thought that would be messy,
it wouldn't work very well.

There are lots of reasons
it wouldn't work.

When you wipe them out, they
look really messy unless you
clean them really nicely.

And in the end I kind
of abandoned that.
I hate whiteboards.

They also look pretty mucky
when you rub them off.

But also it's just, whiteboards
just remind me of

corporate conferences and school
and I don't really want
Numberphile to be like that.

Obviously you could do something
with electronic

tablets and whatnot but I
thought that might be a little
bit Khan Academy.

And I quite liked the
idea of brown paper.

I didn't like the idea of
white paper because--

and this is another reason
whiteboards aren't too good--

a really white background is not
very good for filming when

you're filming people's faces
and the whiteboard.

It becomes very difficult to
control certain aspects of the
picture while you're filming.

Whereas brown paper is
a bit nicer for that.

And I also just like the kind
of the rustic, rich,

ruggedness of the brown paper,
that kind of back of an

envelope, napkin type
feel that I like
Numberphile to have.

I like it to feel
very informal.

And I also really like the idea
of being able to keep the
artifacts afterwards.

Initially I was putting
them all onto Flickr.

And I still put a lot
of them onto Flickr.

If you look at the Numberphile
Flickr, you can go and look at

previous bits of paper
we've used.

I will say lately I've started
putting a few of them on eBay

for various reasons, to either
raise money for charity or to

raise a bit of extra money for
some of the things we do with
Numberphile that cost money.
I've got some here.

Here's a whole bunch of brown
papers from some previous,
some upcoming videos.
So I've started keeping them.

I used to throw them away after
they'd been scanned and
put onto Flickr.

And now I realize that some
people quite like them and
would like to keep them.

So I'm hanging on to
as many as I can.

Occasionally I'll give one away
or put one on eBay for

some reason, so keep an eye out
for that kind of thing on

Twitter and Facebook
and whatnot.

So anyway, there are
few other reasons I
quite like brown paper.
I won't go into them all now.

I know some people don't like
the noise of the markers on
the brown paper.

And we've changed the markers
since the start, because the

first markers we used were
a bit of a mistake.

And I also am trying
to do a bit more
with the sound editing.

"Out of focus." That's
interesting.

camera and I'm having a few

problems with the lights as
well causing flicker.

So if you want to leave
some more comments--

but any problems with the camera
at the moment, I'll be

looking back over this
video and trying to
sort out so, apologies.

It's a bit of a learning
curve.
You guys are helping me learn.

paper company?" No, but if you

I'm being asked things about
Planck length and
the speed of light.

And again that's one

And then we'll be doing this.

Tomorrow, Valentine's Day,
February 14, 2013.
4:00 PM in the UK.

You can do the math for

So when you turn that globe

Which of course is very
